guideline.name: Annotation of DPWG Guideline for escitalopram and CYP2C19

relatedGenes.name: cytochrome P450 family 2 subfamily C member 19

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166299133

text.html: Avoid escitalopram. Antidepressants that are not metabolised or that are metabolised to a lesser extent by CYP2C19 are, for example, paroxetine or fluvoxamine.

implications: The risk of switching to another antidepressant is increased as the gene variation leads to a reduction in the escitalopram plasma concentration.

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166299136

text.html: Do not exceed the following doses (75% of the standard maximum dose): adults < 65 years 15 mg/day, =65 years 7.5 mg/day

implications: The risk of QT prolongation and torsades de pointes is theoretically increased because the gene variation leads to an increased escitalopram plasma concentration. If you follow the dose recommendation below, the increased plasma concentration and the theoretically increased risk of QT prolongation will be offset.

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166299135

text.html: The guideline does not provide a recommendation for escitalopram in normal metabolizers.

implications: The guideline does not provide a description of the impact of a normal metabolizer phenotype on escitalopram.

recommendations.name: Recommendation PA166299134

text.html: Do not exceed the following doses (50% of the standard maximum dose): adults < 65 years 10 mg/day, =65 years 5 mg/day

implications: The risk of switching to another antidepressant is increased. In addition, the risk of QT prolongation and torsades de pointes is theoretically increased because the gene variation leads to an increased escitalopram plasma concentration. If you follow the dose recommendation below, the increased plasma concentration, the theoretically increased risk of QT prolongation and the increased risk of switching to another antidepressant will be offset.
